questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of leprosy can result in hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in the treatment of leprosy that is known to cause hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This hyperpigmentation can affect the skin, resulting in a reddish-brown to nearly black discoloration. The effect is not limited to the skin; it can also cause discoloration of body fluids such as sweat and urine, potentially leading to staining of clothing.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Incorrect as Dapsone, while used in leprosy treatment, is not typically associated with hyperpigmentation.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Incorrect because Ofloxacin, an antibiotic used in some leprosy treatment regimens, does not cause hyperpigmentation as a common side effect.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Incorrect as Rifampicin, though it can cause orange-red discoloration of urine and other body fluids, is not associated with skin hyperpigmentation in the way clofazimine is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine, a drug used in leprosy treatment, can cause significant hyperpigmentation of the skin and discoloration of body fluids, which can be an important consideration in patient counseling and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ambrisentan

 

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) management depends on the results of the vasoreactivity test. In patients with a negative vasoreactivity test, calcium channel blockers such as nifedipine are not effective. Instead, treatment typically involves the use of endothelin receptor antagonists, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, or prostanoids.

 

For a patient with WHO functional class II PAH and a negative vasoreactivity test, the next step in management often includes endothelin receptor antagonists like Ambrisentan. Ambrisentan works by blocking the effects of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, thereby reducing pulmonary vascular resistance and improving symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iloprost: Iloprost is a prostacyclin analog, used primarily in more advanced stages of PAH (class III or IV) or when other treatments have failed. It is not typically the first-line treatment for class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Option C. Nifedipine: Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is used in patients with a positive vasoreactivity test. Since this patient has a negative vasoreactivity test, nifedipine is not appropriate.

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Epoprostenol is another prostacyclin analog used in advanced PAH (class III or IV) or refractory cases. It is not typically used for initial treatment in class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In class II and class III pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), the best option is to use a combination of a phosphodiesterase inhibitor like Tadalafil and an endothelin receptor antagonist like Ambrisentan. Combination therapy is preferred, even though it may not be listed in all options. For refractory class III and class IV PAH patients, prostanoids are used.

questions.text: 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination she has well developed secondary sexual characters and labs revealed a normal LH and FSH. Her karyotype is 46XX. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian Agenesis

 

Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The key features supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  1. Primary amenorrhea in a 16-year-old girl
  2. Well-developed secondary sexual characters
  3. Normal LH and FSH levels
  4. 46,XX karyotype

 

In Mullerian agenesis, the uterus and upper vagina fail to develop properly, but the ovaries function normally. This explains the presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal hormone levels, despite the absence of menstruation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Gonadal Dyagenesis: Incorrect because patients with gonadal dysgenesis typically have high FSH and LH levels due to lack of negative feedback from functioning gonads. They also often lack secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome: Incorrect, isolated GnRH deficiency which is characterized by low LH and FSH levels, absent secondary sexual characteristics, and often associated with anosmia (loss of smell). The patient in this case has normal hormone levels and well-developed secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Incorrect because this condition has a 46,XY karyotype, not 46,XX as in this case. Additionally, individuals with complete AIS would present with female external genitalia but lack a uterus and ovaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, normal hormone levels (LH and FSH), and a 46,XX karyotype.

questions.text: Inhaled NO is used in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension

 

Inhaled nitric oxide (NO) is a potent pulmonary vasodilator used primarily in the management of various conditions associated with elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Its primary uses include:

 

  • Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension (A): Inhaled NO is used to reduce pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular afterload in patients with primary pulmonary hypertension. It helps improve oxygenation and reduce symptoms associated with this condition.
  • Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Inhaled NO can be used to lower pulmonary pressures and relieve right ventricular strain.
  • Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH): Inhaled NO is used for vasoreactivity testing and to manage secondary forms of PAH.
  • Right Ventricular Failure in STEMI: Particularly in inferior STEMI with right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI), inhaled NO can reduce right ventricular afterload.
  • Refractory Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Used as a bridging therapy to improve oxygenation until a more definitive treatment, such as lung transplantation, is available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: This condition is typically managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy and lifestyle modifications.

 

Option C. Unstable Angina: Managed with anti-anginal medications, antiplatelet therapy, and revascularization procedures as needed.

 

Option D. Erectile Dysfunction: Treated with phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil), hormone therapy, or mechanical devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled nitric oxide is primarily used to manage conditions with elevated pulmonary artery pressures, such as primary pulmonary artery hypertension. It is not used for obstructive sleep apnea, unstable angina, or erectile dysfunction.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are the complications associated with GERD? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Asthma
  2. Laryngitis
  3. Pulmonary Fibrosis
  4. Chronic cough
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic condition where stomach contents flow back into the esophagus, causing various symptoms and complications. The complications of GERD can extend beyond the esophagus, affecting the respiratory system and other areas.

 

  1. Asthma: GERD can exacerbate asthma symptoms. The reflux of stomach acid can irritate the airways and lungs, triggering asthma attacks or making existing asthma more difficult to control.
  2. Laryngitis: Acid reflux can lead to inflammation of the larynx (voice box), causing laryngitis. Symptoms may include hoarseness, throat pain, and voice changes.
  3. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Although less common, chronic aspiration of gastric contents due to GERD can contribute to the development of pulmonary fibrosis. This is particularly seen in patients with diffuse scleroderma, where severe GERD is a significant risk factor for interstitial lung disease (ILD).
  4. Chronic cough: GERD is a recognized cause of chronic cough. The reflux of acid can irritate the esophagus and respiratory tract, leading to a persistent cough.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can lead to a variety of extra-esophageal complications, including asthma, laryngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic cough. Recognizing these complications is crucial for the comprehensive management of patients with GERD.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ocrelizumab

 

Ocrelizumab is the preferred drug for the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). PPMS is a form of multiple sclerosis characterized by a gradual progression of neurological symptoms without relapses. The reference paragraph highlights that Ocrelizumab is the only drug that has been shown to be effective in treating PPMS based on recent clinical trials. Ocrelizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20-positive B cells, which are believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Natalizumab: This drug is used primarily for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). It works by inhibiting the migration of immune cells into the central nervous system, but it has not been shown to be effective in PPMS.

 

Option C. Fingolimod: While Fingolimod is effective in treating RRMS, it is not the preferred treatment for PPMS. Fingolimod works by modulating sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors to prevent lymphocytes from reaching the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Alemtuzumab: This drug is used for RRMS and works by depleting circulating T and B lymphocytes. It has not been demonstrated to be effective in treating PPMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocrelizumab is the only drug currently shown to be effective in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS).

 

Remember - The drug that has been shown to be effective in treating secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) is Siponimod, which is a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor agonist.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?(INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block


The ECG shows bradycardia with regular, constant PR intervals in the conducted beats and intermittently dropped QRS complexes, which are indicative of Mobitz type 2 block. This type of atrioventricular block is characterized by:

 

  • Constant PR interval in the conducted beats
  • Intermittent non-conducted P waves (dropped QRS complexes)

 

This distinguishes Mobitz type 2 block from other types of heart block:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>200 ms) but all P waves are followed by QRS complexes. This is not observed in the given ECG.

 

Option B. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no relationship between them. The given ECG does not show this pattern.

 

Option C. Wenckebach heart block (Mobitz type 1): Progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped. The given ECG shows constant PR intervals, not progressively increasing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mobitz type 2 block is identified by a constant PR interval with intermittently non-conducted P waves. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for appropriate management, as Mobitz type 2 can progress to complete heart block and often requires a pacemaker.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

For a 60-year-old patient with diabetes and hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg), it is critical to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Current guidelines, including the 2023 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines, recommend initiating antihypertensive therapy in such patients due to the high risk of cardiovascular events. Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is an appropriate choice for initial antihypertensive therapy in diabetic patients. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is well-tolerated, without negatively impacting glycemic control. Ideally, an ACE inhibitor or ARB would be preferred, but if not available, a calcium channel blocker like amlodipine is a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not first-line therapy for hypertension unless there is a specific indication such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, or angina. Beta-blockers are not the preferred initial treatment for hypertensive diabetics.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modifications are important, they are insufficient alone for managing hypertension in a diabetic patient, who is at high cardiovascular risk.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not typically used as first-line therapy for hypertension. It may be used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but offers no additional advantage in this context and may cause orthostatic hypotension, worsening dizziness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method to assess the success of H. pylori eradication therapy. It works by detecting the presence of urease, an enzyme produced by H. pylori. During the test, the patient ingests a urea solution labeled with a carbon isotope. If H. pylori is present, the urease enzyme breaks down the urea, releasing labeled carbon dioxide, which is then measured in the patient's breath. This test is highly accurate, non-invasive, and convenient for follow-up, making it the best choice for confirming the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy: While endoscopy with a biopsy for a rapid urease test can be used to detect H. pylori, it is invasive and not ideal for follow-up assessments when less invasive options are available.

 

Option B. IgG antibody study: This test detects antibodies against H. pylori but is not useful for follow-up after treatment. Antibody levels can remain elevated for a long time even after the infection has been eradicated, leading to false-positive results.

 

Option D. Urease test of biopsy: This method, similar to endoscopy, involves an invasive procedure to obtain a gastric tissue sample for a rapid urease test. Although accurate, it is not preferred for follow-up due to its invasiveness compared to non-invasive options like the urea breath test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method for assessing the success of H. pylori eradication therapy due to its accuracy and convenience.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide vaccine? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B vaccine

 

The Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a subunit vaccine containing surface antigen of the Hepatitis B virus. Polysaccharide vaccines are composed of long chains of sugar molecules that make up the surface capsule of certain bacteria. The Hepatitis B vaccine, in contrast, uses protein antigens from the virus's surface.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hib vaccine: This is a polysaccharide vaccine. It targets Haemophilus influenzae type b, a bacterium with a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Option C. Meningococcal vaccine: This is also a polysaccharide vaccine, designed to protect against Neisseria meningitidis, which has a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Option D. Pneumococcal vaccine: This is a polysaccharide vaccine as well, targeting Streptococcus pneumoniae, another bacterium with a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are four main polysaccharide vaccines in practice, which can be remembered by the mnemonic "SHINT":

 

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococcal),
  • Haemophilus influenzae (Hib),
  • Neisseria meningitidis (Meningococcal), and
  • Typhoid (Salmonella typhi).

 

The Hepatitis B vaccine is not part of this group as it's a subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

 

Hemiballismus is characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements, typically on one side of the body. This condition is most commonly associated with a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating movements, and damage to this area can lead to the excessive, uncontrolled movements seen in hemiballismus. This differentiates it from lesions in other parts of the basal ganglia, which are associated with different movement disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Lesions in the putamen are more commonly associated with chorea, which involves rapid, involuntary, and irregular movements, rather than the violent flinging movements of hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus: Similar to the putamen, lesions in the caudate nucleus typically result in chorea. The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum, and its dysfunction does not usually present with the violent movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus: Lesions in the globus pallidus often result in athetosis, which involves slow, writhing movements. This is different from the abrupt and forceful movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

choices.text: X-linked Agammaglobulinemia
Chronic Granulomatous Disease
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency
Chediak-Higashi syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following presents with repeated catalase-positive infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is characterized by repeated catalase-positive infections. The key feature here is the defective NADPH oxidase complex, most commonly due to mutations in the CYBB gene. This defect impairs the neutrophils' ability to produce a respiratory burst, resulting in a killing defect. Patients can phagocytose organisms but cannot effectively kill them, leading to persistent and repeated infections. These infections often result in chronic pus formation, abscesses, and granulomas, which can cause obstructive symptoms in various organ systems.

 

The catalase-positive organisms commonly associated with CGD can be remembered using the mnemonic PACEBAT:

 

P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa

A - Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus, Actinomyces israeli

C - Corynebacterium, Candida

E - Enterobacteriaceae (e.g., E. coli)

B - Burkholderia cepacia complex

A - Actinomyces israeli (repeated)

T - Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis)

 

CGD is typically inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, although autosomal recessive forms exist.

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), which can be diagnosed with:

 

  • NBT (Nitroblue Tetrazolium) test
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test, a flow cytometry-based test.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia: Incorrect because this condition is characterized by a lack of B cells and immunoglobulins, leading to bacterial infections but not specifically catalase-positive infections. It typically manifests after 4 months of age when maternal antibodies wane.

 

Option C. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency: Incorrect as SCID involves defects in both T and B cells, causing severe infections early in life (within weeks of birth). While it can include both bacterial and fungal infections, it's not specifically associated with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Note - Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) can be caused by:

 

  • ADA deficiency (Adenosine Deaminase deficiency)
  • RAG-1/2 deficiency (Recombination Activating Genes 1 and 2 deficiency)
  • Interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL-2RG) deficiency

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Incorrect because although it involves repeated infections due to neutrophil function defects, it's primarily characterized by partial albinism, giant granules in leukocytes, and bleeding tendencies. It's not specifically associated with catalase-positive infections.

 

Note - Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is due to LYST gene defect and presents with a classic triad:

 

  • Oculocutaneous albinism
  • Recurrent infections
  • Neurological abnormalities

 

Giant azurophilic granules within neutrophils are a characteristic feature of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is characterized by repeated catalase-positive infections due to defective NADPH oxidase complex, impacting the ability of phagocytes to kill ingested microorganisms.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Headache for > 4 hours
  2. Worst headache of life
  3. New-onset progressive headache
  4. Headache with blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) 2, 3, 4

 

Certain types of headaches can be indicative of serious underlying conditions and thus require further evaluation to rule out life-threatening or severe pathologies:

 

2. Worst headache of life: This is a classic description of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. Patients experiencing this type of headache require immediate medical attention and thorough investigation, typically involving neuroimaging.

 

3. New-onset progressive headache: Progressive headaches, especially those that are new in onset and occur in adults, raise concern for potential serious conditions such as brain tumors or other intracranial pathologies. These headaches warrant detailed medical evaluation.

 

4. Headache with blurring of vision: This symptom combination suggests possible increased intracranial pressure, which can be associated with conditions like papilledema or optic neuritis. Such cases need prompt assessment to determine the cause and appropriate management.

 

Other Option:

 

1. Headache for > 4 hours: While a headache lasting more than four hours can be distressing, it is not necessarily indicative of a severe underlying condition. Such headaches could be primary headaches like tension-type headaches or migraines, which often do not require immediate further evaluation unless they have other alarming features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headaches described as the "worst headache of life," new-onset progressive headaches, and headaches accompanied by blurring of vision require further medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of diabetes is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is a biguanide used as a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. One of the most common and significant side effects of metformin is gastrointestinal disturbances, particularly diarrhea. This side effect is due to the drug’s effect on the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause alterations in bowel habits, including watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione and is not typically associated with diarrhea. Its side effects include fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option B. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. While it can cause gastrointestinal side effects, it is more commonly associated with symptoms like indigestion, nausea, and bloating rather than diarrhea.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea and is generally not associated with diarrhea. Its side effects typically include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea as a side effect, making it important for healthcare providers to monitor patients for this gastrointestinal disturbance when prescribing the medication.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

choices.text: Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage
Perform endoscopy to assess for varices
Initiate treatment with thiamine and lorazepam

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic alcoholism presents to the emergency department with vomiting, altered sensorium, and hypotension. His last binge drinking episode was 7 days ago. An ultrasound reveals a small liver with coarse echotexture and mild portal vein dilation. Given these findings, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initiate treatment with thiamine and lorazepam

 

In a chronic alcoholic presenting with altered sensorium, vomiting, and hypotension, the most critical differential diagnosis to consider is Wernicke's encephalopathy. This condition is caused by thiamine deficiency and is a medical emergency. It must be treated promptly to prevent permanent brain damage.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Wernicke's Encephalopathy: It is characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. However, not all patients present with the complete triad, and altered mental status may be the most prominent feature. Chronic alcoholism is a significant risk factor for thiamine deficiency.
  • Thiamine Administration: Immediate administration of thiamine is crucial before any glucose administration, as glucose can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy in thiamine-deficient patients.
  • Lorazepam: In patients with cirrhosis or liver dysfunction, lorazepam is preferred over long-acting benzodiazepines like chlordiazepoxide due to its safer hepatic profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage: Lactulose is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy by reducing ammonia levels. However, in this patient, the more urgent concern is Wernicke's encephalopathy due to the presenting symptoms and chronic alcoholism history.

 

Option B. Perform endoscopy to assess for varices: Endoscopy may be necessary to assess for varices, especially in a patient with signs of portal hypertension and liver cirrhosis. However, it is not the immediate next step in an emergency setting where the patient presents with altered sensorium and the primary concern is Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Administer chlordiazepoxide: Chlordiazepoxide is a long-acting benzodiazepine used in alcohol withdrawal. However, this patient last drank 7 days ago, making withdrawal less likely the primary issue. Additionally, chlordiazepoxide is not recommended in patients with liver dysfunction due to its long half-life and risk of accumulation. Lorazepam or oxazepam, which have safer profiles in liver dysfunction, would be better choices if benzodiazepines are needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a chronic alcoholic presenting with altered sensorium, the immediate administration of thiamine is crucial to treat potential Wernicke's encephalopathy. Lorazepam can be used for its safer hepatic profile if benzodiazepine administration is necessary. The focus should be on treating the most urgent and reversible conditions first.

questions.text: What is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileocecal junction

 

The ileocecal junction is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis. This area, which includes the terminal ileum and the beginning of the large intestine (cecum), is particularly susceptible to infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The lymphoid tissue in this region provides a favorable environment for the bacteria to proliferate.

 

Abdominal tuberculosis can present in two primary forms: hypertrophic and ulcerative. The hypertrophic form involves thickening of the intestinal wall, while the ulcerative form leads to the formation of ulcers. Clinically, differentiating abdominal tuberculosis from Crohn's disease can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms and similar radiologic findings. In some cases, empirical anti-tubercular therapy (ATP) may be initiated, with subsequent monitoring for clinical improvement to help distinguish between the two conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectum: The rectum is not a common site for abdominal tuberculosis. Tuberculosis primarily affects the ileocecal region and less frequently involves other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Colon: While tuberculosis can affect the colon, it is not the most common site. The ileocecal junction is more frequently involved in abdominal tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Small intestine: Although the small intestine can be affected, the terminal ileum specifically, which is part of the ileocecal junction, is the most common site for tuberculosis within the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site of abdominal tuberculosis is the ileocecal junction, particularly near the terminal ileum. This region's lymphoid tissue creates a favorable environment for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to proliferate.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Thyroid scan
  2. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
  3. Thyroid function tests
  4. Ultrasound of neck
  5. Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, and 5 only

 

The clinical presentation of neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests hyperthyroidism, likely Graves' disease.

 

FNAC is not recommended in this case because it does not provide additional diagnostic yield for Graves' disease, does not alter the treatment plan, and carries a risk of complications due to the gland's increased vascularity in Graves' disease.

 

Other Options:

 

The following investigations are essential:

 

1. Thyroid scan: A radioactive iodine uptake scan helps differentiate between diffuse uptake (indicative of Graves' disease) and nodular uptake (indicative of toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).

 

3. Thyroid function tests: These are crucial as they provide information on the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), helping confirm the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

 

4. Ultrasound of neck: This imaging modality helps assess the thyroid gland's structure and can reveal increased vascularity, which is characteristic of Graves' disease.

 

5. Anti-thyroid antibody: Testing for antibodies, such as TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs) or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), is important for diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases like Graves' disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with clinical signs of hyperthyroidism and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, essential investigations include a thyroid scan, thyroid function tests, ultrasound of the neck, and anti-thyroid antibody tests. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not typically required in these cases.

questions.text:
A patient with an unknown blood group experiences trauma and is unstable, requiring an urgent blood transfusion. Which types of blood should be transfused? (multiple choice) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. A+
b. AB+
c. O+
d. O-
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c & d

 

Explanation

 

In emergency situations where a patient’s blood type is unknown and an urgent blood transfusion is required, the safest choice is to use blood that minimizes the risk of adverse reactions.

 

Universal Donor:

 

d. O- (O Negative): O negative blood is considered the universal donor for red blood cells because it lacks A, B, and Rh antigens, which means it can be safely given to any patient regardless of their blood type. This is the safest option and is preferred when available.

 

c. O+ (O Positive): In situations where O negative blood is not available, O positive blood can be used, especially in adult males and females beyond childbearing age, as it still minimizes the risk of severe hemolytic reactions. O positive blood can be safely given to any Rh-positive patient and is often used when O negative supplies are limited.

 

Other Options

 

a. A+: A positive blood can only be given to patients with A+ or AB+ blood types due to the presence of A antigens and the Rh factor, making it unsuitable for universal emergency transfusions.

 

b. AB+: AB positive blood is the universal recipient, meaning people with AB+ blood can receive any blood type, but it is not a universal donor. AB+ blood can only be given to other AB+ patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency situations requiring urgent blood transfusions for patients with unknown blood types, O negative blood is the universal donor and the safest choice. If O negative is not available, O positive can also be used to minimize the risk of adverse reactions.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: Best investigation for malaria speciation identification - (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for malaria species identification. This technique provides a single layer of red blood cells (RBCs), allowing for clear visualization of the parasite's morphology. The Giemsa stain enhances the visibility of the parasite's features, making it easier to distinguish between different Plasmodium species based on their characteristic appearances within the RBCs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Thick smear: While useful for screening and detecting the presence of malaria parasites, thick smears contain multiple layers of RBCs and often deform the cells. This makes it difficult to accurately identify specific Plasmodium species.

 

Option B. Thin smear with acridine orange: This method, also known as the Kawamoto technique, stains only nucleic acids. While it highlights the parasites, it doesn't stain the RBCs, making it challenging to observe the parasite's relationship to the host cell and thus complicating species identification. (screening test)

 

Option D. Buffy Coat: This is a modified acridine orange-based test using a capillary tube instead of a slide. It's primarily a screening method to detect the presence of malaria parasites but is not suitable for species identification. (screening test)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin blood smears stained with Giemsa are the gold standard for malaria species identification due to their ability to clearly show parasite morphology within a single layer of RBCs.

questions.text: All of the following are growth promoting proto-oncogenes except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF beta

 

TGF beta (Transforming Growth Factor beta) is the exception in this list as it is not a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. Instead, TGF beta is a classic example of a tumor suppressor protein. The TGF-beta/SMAD complex acts as a tumor suppressor complex, inhibiting cell growth and promoting apoptosis in normal cells. Loss of function mutations in the TGF-beta pathway can contribute to cancer development by removing this growth-inhibitory signal.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. FGF (Fibroblast Growth Factor): FGF is indeed a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It stimulates cell proliferation and survival in various cell types.

 

Option B. PDGF (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor): PDGF is a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It plays a crucial role in cell growth, division, and blood vessel formation.

 

Option C. TGF alpha (Transforming Growth Factor alpha): TGF alpha is a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It stimulates cell proliferation and is often overexpressed in various cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among growth factors, TGF beta stands out as a tumor suppressor, while FGF, PDGF, and TGF alpha are growth-promoting proto-oncogenes. Understanding the distinct roles of these factors is crucial in comprehending cancer biology and developing targeted therapies.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in the treatment of hemophilia B? (multiple choice) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a)  Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
b)  Cryoprecipitate
c)  Factor VIII concentrates
d)  Cryo poor Plasma
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a & d

 

Explanation

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of factor IX. The primary treatment for hemophilia B involves the replacement of the missing factor IX.

 

Treatment Options: Factor IX concentrates: The specific treatment for hemophilia B is the administration of factor IX concentrates, which directly replace the deficient clotting factor.

 

a. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP): FFP contains all the clotting factors, including factor IX, in certain proportions. It can be used as a treatment for hemophilia B, especially in situations where factor IX concentrates are not available. FFP serves as a "poor man's alternative" due to its comprehensive content of clotting factors.

 

d. Cryopoor Plasma: This is FFP from which the cryoprecipitate has been removed. While cryoprecipitate contains high levels of factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen, the cryopoor plasma retains significant amounts of factor IX. Therefore, cryopoor plasma can be used as an alternative treatment for hemophilia B. (preferred over FFP)

 

Other Options:

 

b. Cryoprecipitate: This blood product is enriched with factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen but contains little to no factor IX, making it unsuitable for treating hemophilia B.

 

c. Factor VIII concentrates: This treatment is specific to hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. It is not effective for hemophilia B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of hemophilia B primarily involves the administration of factor IX concentrates. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) and cryopoor plasma are also viable options due to their content of factor IX. Factor VIII concentrates and cryoprecipitate are not suitable for hemophilia B as they do not contain significant levels of factor IX.

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myxedema coma

 

The patient presents with several symptoms indicative of severe hypothyroidism. These include altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, bradycardia, non-pitting edema, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. In hypothyroid patients, a severe, life-threatening condition called myxedema coma can develop. This is characterized by a profound deficiency of thyroid hormones, leading to critical manifestations such as altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and edema.

 

Myxedema coma requires immediate medical intervention. The treatment of choice involves intravenous administration of thyroxine (IV T4) and IV hydrocortisone. IV hydrocortisone is essential because many patients with myxedema coma have subtle adrenal insufficiency, which can become overt with the initiation of thyroid hormone replacement. This combination helps stabilize the patient's condition and addresses both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic shock: While this condition involves hypotension and altered sensorium, it is usually associated with signs of infection, fever, and a source of sepsis, which are not described in this patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: This condition involves heart failure and typically presents with signs of fluid overload, severe breathlessness, and possibly chest pain, none of which are noted in this patient’s history.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: The symptoms of hyperthyroidism include weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, and increased bowel movements, which are opposite to the symptoms exhibited by this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening condition of profound hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as altered sensorium, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema. Immediate treatment involves IV thyroxine and IV hydrocortisone to manage both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiency

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease has elevated serum creatinine and urea levels. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents is safe to use? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linagliptin

 

Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) require careful selection of hypoglycemic agents due to altered drug excretion and the risk of further renal impairment. Among the given options, linagliptin is the safest choice for such patients. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, including those on hemodialysis. This is because linagliptin is primarily excreted via the liver rather than the kidneys.

 

Note – Certain GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide can be used without dose adjustment according to the latest studies. Additionally, pioglitazone can also be used without dose adjustment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: This sulfonylurea can cause hypoglycemia and requires dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, making it less suitable for those with elevated serum creatinine and urea levels.

 

Option B. Exenatide: This GLP-1 receptor agonist is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min) due to the risk of accumulation and potential toxicity.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Another DPP-4 inhibitor, vildagliptin requires dose adjustment in renal impairment, making it less favorable compared to linagliptin for patients with CKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is the preferred oral hypoglycemic agent for patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease, as it does not require dose adjustment and is safely excreted by the liver.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for the treatment of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amyl nitrite
  2. Sodium nitrite
  3. Sodium thiosulfate
  4. Glyceryl trinitrate
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

Cyanide poisoning is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt treatment to prevent severe toxicity. The best treatment for cyanide poisoning is IV hydroxycobalamin (Vitamin B12).

 

Other alternative drugs are:

 

  1. Amyl nitrite: This drug induces the formation of methemoglobin, which can bind cyanide ions and form cyanmethemoglobin, thereby preventing cyanide from inhibiting cytochrome oxidase enzymes.
  2. Sodium nitrite: Similar to amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite also induces the formation of methemoglobin. This treatment is administered intravenously for more rapid effect compared to amyl nitrite.
  3. Sodium thiosulfate: This acts as a sulfur donor, converting cyanide to the less toxic thiocyanate, which is then excreted in the urine. Sodium thiosulfate is often used in conjunction with nitrites to enhance cyanide detoxification.

 

Other option:

 

  1. Glyceryl trinitrate: This drug is primarily used in the management of angina and works as a vasodilator. It is not effective for the treatment of cyanide poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary drugs used for the treatment of cyanide poisoning are amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulfate. Glyceryl trinitrate is not effective in this context.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Syringomyelia

 

Syringomyelia is characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity or syrinx within the spinal cord, which typically expands over time. This condition most commonly affects the cervical and thoracic regions of the spinal cord. The classic presentation includes a loss of pain and temperature sensation in a "cape-like" distribution over the shoulders and back, while touch, vibration, and proprioception (posterior column sensations) remain intact. This pattern of sensory loss is due to the disruption of the decussating (crossing) fibers of the spinothalamic tract, which carry pain and temperature sensations. The cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord is a hallmark of syringomyelia and leads to the aforementioned symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Brown-Sequard syndrome: This condition results from hemisection or damage to one half of the spinal cord. It typically presents with ipsilateral motor loss and loss of proprioception and vibration sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This does not match the described symptoms and imaging findings.

 

Option B. Tabes dorsalis: This is a late manifestation of neurosyphilis, characterized by degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, leading to impaired proprioception and vibration sense, ataxia, and lightning pains. It does not cause cavitation around the central canal or the specific dissociated sensory loss seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Syringobulbia: This is a similar condition to syringomyelia but involves the brainstem (medulla oblongata) rather than the spinal cord. It presents with symptoms related to cranial nerve involvement such as dysphagia, dysarthria, and facial pain. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are more consistent with syringomyelia, not syringobulbia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syringomyelia presents with a loss of pain and temperature sensation while preserving touch sensation, and is characterized by cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord.

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%.
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.
ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%.
AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases.

questions.text: All are true regarding heart failure except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.

 

Non-cardiovascular death refers to mortality due to causes other than cardiovascular diseases, such as infections, accidents, or malignancies.

 

The majority of deaths in HFrEF (Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction) are due to cardiovascular causes (85%), and only 15% are due to non-cardiovascular causes.

 

In contrast, in HFpEF (Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction), 60% of deaths are cardiovascular, and 40% are non-cardiovascular.

 

Therefore, non-cardiovascular death is actually more prevalent in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients, making option B incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%: This statement is correct. Both HFpEF and HFrEF patients have similar 5-year mortality rates, approximately 50%. This indicates that having a preserved ejection fraction does not necessarily correlate with a better long-term survival rate compared to reduced ejection fraction.

 

Option C. ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%: This statement is correct. Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are known to cause a persistent cough in about 15% of patients and angioedema, a more serious but less common side effect, in approximately 1% of patients.

 

Option D. AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases: This statement is correct. Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is indeed common among elderly patients and is a significant cause of cardioembolic strokes, accounting for about 25% of such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-cardiovascular deaths are more common in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest X-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray findings indicate pleural effusion. Key features of pleural effusion on a chest X-ray include the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. Clinically, pleural effusion leads to reduced or absent air entry in the affected area.

 

A dull note on percussion is a hallmark sign of pleural effusion. This occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which does not transmit sound vibrations as efficiently as air-filled lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperresonance on percussion: This finding is characteristic of pneumothorax, where there is an excess of air in the pleural space, leading to increased resonance.

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: Coarse crackles can be heard in various conditions such as bronchiectasis, the resolving phase of pneumonia, or pulmonary edema. However, they are not typically associated with pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub is a sign of pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura. It is usually absent in pleural effusion due to the separation of pleural surfaces by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dull note on percussion is a key clinical finding in pleural effusion, indicating the presence of fluid in the pleural space.

questions.text: Match the blood product with the shelf life mentioned in the next column: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

The shelf lives of various blood products are crucial for ensuring their efficacy and safety in clinical use. Here is the matching of blood products with their respective shelf lives:

 

Single donor platelet (A): These typically have a shelf life of 5 days (3.).

 

Packed red blood cells (B): These can be stored for up to 42 days depending on the preservative used (1.).

 

Cryoprecipitate (C): This blood product has a shelf life of 1 year when stored properly (4.).

 

Granulocyte concentrate (D): This product has a short shelf life of 24 hours (2.).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shelf life of different blood products is essential for proper storage and timely usage in medical practice.

 

  • Single donor platelet - 5 days
  • Packed red blood cells - 42 days
  • Cryoprecipitate - 1 year
  • Granulocyte concentrate - 24 hours

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:
