In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are criteria for anaphylaxis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting
  2. Hypertension
  3. Urticaria and swollen lips
  4. Respiratory distress
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, c & d

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and requires immediate medical attention. The diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis typically involve the acute onset of symptoms affecting multiple organ systems.

 

a. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting: These are gastrointestinal symptoms that can be part of anaphylaxis when present with other criteria.

 

c. Urticaria and swollen lips: These are common skin manifestations of anaphylaxis.

 

d. Respiratory distress: Respiratory compromise is a key feature of anaphylaxis.

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Anaphylaxis (Acute onset – within minutes to hours)

 

Involvement of the skin, mucosal tissue + ≥ 1 of the following:

a. Respiratory compromise (e.g., dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, hypoxemia)

b. Hypotension or associated symptoms

 

≥ 2 of the following:

a. Involvement of the skin mucosal tissue

b. Respiratory compromise

c. Hypotension or associated symptoms

d. Persistent GI symptoms

 

Reduced BP after exposure to known allergen:

A. Infants and children – Low SBP (adjusted to age) or > 30% decrease in SBP

B. Adults – SBP < 90 mmHg or > 30% decrease in SBP

 

Other Option:

 

Option b. Hypertension: Anaphylaxis is typically associated with hypotension, not hypertension. Hypotension is a significant marker for the severity of the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that involves multiple organ systems and is characterized by symptoms such as urticaria, swollen lips, respiratory distress, and persistent gastrointestinal symptoms. Hypotension, rather than hypertension, is a critical diagnostic feature. Recognizing these criteria promptly is crucial for the immediate management of anaphylaxis.

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a key diagnostic tool in the evaluation of neurological conditions, particularly epilepsy. However, it is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures. A patient can have seizures even if their EEG results are normal. An abnormal EEG can provide reassurance of a diagnosis of epilepsy when the clinical context supports it, but a normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy or seizures. Therefore, making an EEG mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges: This statement is correct. Epileptiform discharges can be present in a small percentage of the general population without necessarily indicating that the individual has epilepsy.

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: This statement is correct. Scalp EEG can indeed help localize the origin of epileptic activity, including frontal lobe epilepsy, although it might not always be definitive.

 

Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: This statement is correct. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and other forms of encephalopathy can show triphasic waves and slow wave patterns on an EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

 

Telmisartan is the appropriate choice for a hypertensive patient with an elevated HbA1c level (8.1%), indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Telmisartan, an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), has unique properties among ARBs due to its partial agonistic activity on peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma). PPAR-gamma agonists can improve insulin sensitivity and have beneficial effects on glycemic control. This makes Telmisartan particularly useful for patients managing both hypertension and diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not have the beneficial effects on glycemic control seen with Telmisartan and would not be the preferred choice in a patient with elevated HbA1c.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. While effective for hypertension, beta-blockers can potentially worsen glycemic control and are not ideal for patients with diabetes.

 

Option D. Olmesartan: Olmesartan is another ARB, but unlike Telmisartan, it lacks PPAR-gamma agonistic activity. Thus, it does not offer the additional benefit of improving insulin sensitivity and glycemic control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: FISH can detect all except which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a cytogenetic technique used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It can detect chromosomal abnormalities such as amplifications, deletions, and translocations. However, FISH cannot detect point mutations because these are small-scale changes in DNA sequence that occur at the molecular level, not at the chromosomal level that FISH is designed to analyze.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amplification: As FISH can detect gene amplifications, which are increases in the number of copies of a particular gene.

 

Option B. Deletion: Because FISH can identify chromosomal deletions, where a segment of a chromosome is missing.

 

Option C. Translocation: As FISH is commonly used to detect chromosomal translocations, where segments of chromosomes have exchanged places.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) can detect chromosomal abnormalities like amplifications, deletions, and translocations, but cannot detect point mutations, which require molecular methods such as PCR for identification.

choices.text: There is no increased risk of colon cancer
Continuous involvement rather than skip lesions

questions.text: In contrast to Ulcerative Colitis, which of the following statements regarding Crohn's disease is true?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perianal fistulas are frequent

 

Perianal fistulas are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis. This is due to the transmural nature of inflammation in Crohn's disease, which affects all layers of the intestinal wall. Fistulas are a result of this deep tissue involvement and are rarely seen in ulcerative colitis, where inflammation is typically limited to the mucosal layer.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. There is no increased risk of colon cancer: This statement is incorrect. Modern studies show that Crohn's disease patients, especially those with colonic involvement, have a risk of colon cancer comparable to that of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Continuous involvement rather than skip lesions: This is incorrect for Crohn's disease. Skip lesions (areas of healthy tissue between inflamed segments) are characteristic of Crohn's disease, while continuous involvement is typical of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option D. Seldom manifests with hematochezia: This statement is also incorrect. Patients with Crohn's disease, particularly those with colonic involvement, can manifest with hematochezia (bloody stools), sometimes even regularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perianal fistulas are a distinctive feature of Crohn's disease due to its transmural nature, setting it apart from ulcerative colitis where such fistulas are rare.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness. The resting pulse was 110 beats per minute. Which of the following tests should be done next to evaluate her condition further? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Explanation:

 

In the evaluation of suspected thyroid dysfunction, the initial and most crucial test is the measurement of Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH). TSH is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid function because even minor changes in thyroid hormone levels cause significant changes in TSH levels due to the feedback mechanism between the thyroid gland and the pituitary gland. Elevated or suppressed TSH levels provide clear insight into whether the thyroid gland is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). Given the patient's symptoms of weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness, hyperthyroidism is suspected, making TSH the appropriate initial test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Total T3: T3 levels can be influenced by various factors and are usually measured after initial TSH and Free T4 tests suggest hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B.  Thyroid Scan: This imaging test evaluates thyroid structure and function, useful in cases where nodules or hyperactivity need to be assessed. It is not the first-line test for evaluating general thyroid function.

 

Option C. Free T4: Free T4 is important in assessing thyroid function and is typically measured alongside TSH. However, TSH is preferred as the initial screening test due to its sensitivity in detecting thyroid dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test for evaluating suspected thyroid dysfunction, particularly in hyperthyroid symptoms, is TSH due to its sensitivity and reliability in reflecting thyroid status.

choices.text: Males and females are equally affected
Characterized by presence of Heinz bodies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of G6PD deficiency? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Males and females are equally affected

 

G6PD (Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase) deficiency is an X-linked recessive genetic disorder. It is the most common enzyme deficiency worldwide and predominantly affects males. Females can be carriers or, in rare cases, affected if they inherit the defective gene from both parents.

 

Males and females are equally affected: This statement is incorrect. G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, meaning that males are predominantly affected, while females are usually carriers. Thus, males and females are not equally affected.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Oxidative stress: G6PD deficiency leads to decreased production of NADPH, which is essential for protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage. The lack of NADPH results in increased oxidative stress within red blood cells.

 

Option C. Due to deficiency of NADPH: G6PD is crucial for the pentose phosphate pathway, which generates NADPH. The deficiency of G6PD leads to a shortage of NADPH, impairing the red blood cells' ability to deal with oxidative stress.

 

Option D. Characterized by presence of Heinz bodies: Heinz bodies are aggregates of denatured hemoglobin found in red blood cells due to oxidative damage. These are characteristic of G6PD deficiency and can be visualized using special stains like new methylene blue.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that predominantly affects males, leads to oxidative stress due to a deficiency of NADPH, and is characterized by the presence of Heinz bodies in red blood cells.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anosmia

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the failure to start or fully complete puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from an isolated deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and consequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Anosmia is the hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome and helps differentiate it from other causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndactyly in males: This refers to the fusion of fingers or toes and is not characteristic of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Precocious puberty in females: This is an early onset of puberty, which is not associated with Kallmann syndrome, as this condition causes delayed or absent puberty.

 

Option D. White forelock: This is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, not Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. The patient does not have any evidence of cirrhosis and her coagulation profile is normal. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. What can be done next? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start ATT

 

In countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis, such as India, the presence of elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid is highly suggestive of abdominal tuberculosis (TB). ADA is a useful diagnostic marker for TB, particularly when its levels are significantly elevated (e.g., above 39 IU/L). Given the clinical context of weight loss, fever, and ascites, along with a high ADA level, it is reasonable to initiate anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without further invasive testing. Starting ATT and monitoring the patient's response is an effective and practical approach, especially in resource-limited settings. This strategy avoids unnecessary invasive procedures like peritoneal biopsy, which should be reserved for cases where there is doubt about the diagnosis or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritoneal Biopsy: While peritoneal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing peritoneal TB, it is invasive and resource-intensive. In high-prevalence areas, where elevated ADA levels strongly suggest TB, initiating ATT is preferred.

 

Option C. Observation: Given the significant clinical symptoms and elevated ADA levels, mere observation is not appropriate. Delay in treatment could lead to worsening of the patient’s condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is an invasive surgical procedure and is not warranted for diagnosing TB when non-invasive methods like ADA testing and clinical presentation strongly suggest the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-prevalence countries for tuberculosis, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid, along with clinical signs, is sufficient to start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without the need for invasive procedures.

choices.text: Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction
Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night
Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness, and his wife also complains that he snores a lot at night during sleep. Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction

 

The patient's symptoms suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a condition characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to disrupted sleep and decreased oxygen levels.

 

 Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction: This statement is incorrect. In obstructive sleep apnea, the problem is actually due to the decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep, which causes the airway to collapse and obstruct. Increased tone of these muscles would actually help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night: This statement is correct. During episodes of apnea, the blood oxygen levels drop, leading to hypoxemia. This triggers arousal from sleep to restore normal breathing, leading to fragmented sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness.

 

Option C. Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart: This statement is correct. The repetitive episodes of apnea and hypoxemia increase the work of breathing and intrathoracic pressure changes, which can increase stress on the heart, leading to potential cardiovascular complications such as hypertension and heart failure.

 

Option D. Hypoxemia stimulates respiratory effort: This statement is correct. Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels) and hypercapnia (high carbon dioxide levels) stimulate the brain's respiratory centers, increasing respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction and restore normal breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstructive sleep apnea, decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep leads to airway collapse and obstruction. Increased muscle tone would help keep the airway open and is not a cause of obstruction in this condition.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

 

The patient presenting with a brownish hue in the blood, coupled with a history of chronic stable angina, points towards methemoglobinemia. Patients with chronic stable angina are often on nitrate therapy, which is a known risk factor for developing methemoglobinemia.

 

Methemoglobinemia occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state, which is unable to bind oxygen effectively. This results in reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and cyanosis. The brownish hue of the blood, often described as chocolate-colored, is characteristic of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxyhemoglobinemia: Carboxyhemoglobinemia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, typically associated with exposure to fire or automobile exhaust. The blood in this condition has a cherry red color, not brownish.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells. It does not cause a brownish hue in the blood.

 

Option D. Sulfhemoglobinemia: Sulfhemoglobinemia results from the incorporation of sulfur into hemoglobin, leading to a greenish or bluish color of the blood, rather than brownish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

  

The ECG provided shows the characteristic pattern of Brugada syndrome, which includes:

 

  1. Pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern in leads V1 and V2.
  2. ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V2).
  3. Coving of the ST segment.
  4. T-wave inversion following the ST-segment elevation.

 

Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, often occurring at rest or during sleep. It is more prevalent in young males and can present with symptoms such as nocturnal chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: Typically presents with ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads but does not usually show the pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and possible left atrial enlargement, often presenting with deep Q waves and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG, not the specific pattern seen here.

 

Option D. DCM (Dilated Cardiomyopathy): Shows global left ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, which can lead to low voltage QRS complexes, left bundle branch block, or non-specific ST-T changes but not the specific Brugada pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients, especially young males, with a history of syncope or nocturnal chest pain presenting with the characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methyl malonic acid
If given at the diagnosis of pregnancy - can prevent neural tube defects
Folate supplementation is required in children with chronic hemolytic anemia
Vitamin B12 deficiency should be corrected before supplementing folate

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding folate deficiency is FALSE? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) If given at the diagnosis of pregnancy - can prevent neural tube defects

 

The statement in option B is false regarding folate deficiency. Neural tube defects cannot be prevented by administering folic acid at the time of pregnancy diagnosis. Prevention of neural tube defects requires preconceptual folic acid supplementation. When folic acid is given before conception and continued during pregnancy, it can reduce the risk of neural tube defects by approximately 60-70%. Administering folic acid only after pregnancy is diagnosed is too late to prevent these defects, as the neural tube closes very early in embryonic development.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methyl malonic acid: This is correct for folate deficiency. High homocysteine is characteristic of folate deficiency, while methyl malonic acid remains normal. Elevated methyl malonic acid is more indicative of B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Folate supplementation is required in children with chronic hemolytic anemia: This statement is correct. In chronic hemolytic conditions, the increased red blood cell turnover creates a higher demand for folate. Additionally, folate stores in the body are limited, lasting only 3-4 months, necessitating supplementation in these cases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency should be corrected before supplementing folate: This is a true statement. In many cases, folate deficiency coexists with B12 deficiency. Treating folate deficiency without addressing B12 deficiency can mask B12 deficiency symptoms and potentially worsen neurological manifestations, even as hematological parameters improve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preconceptual folic acid supplementation, not supplementation at pregnancy diagnosis, is crucial for preventing neural tube defects.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy
  5. ECG
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

The patient presents with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar of 205 mg/dl), indicating diabetes. The appropriate investigations for a newly diagnosed diabetic patient are:

 

1. HbA1c: To assess long-term glycemic control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

2. Urine ACR (Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio): To screen for diabetic nephropathy, as microalbuminuria is an early sign of kidney damage.

 

4. Fundoscopy: To check for diabetic retinopathy and other microvascular changes in the eyes.

 

5. ECG: To screen for any cardiovascular complications, as diabetes increases the risk of heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Echocardiography: Not a routine screening test for diabetes unless there is a specific indication, such as suspected heart failure or structural heart disease.

 

6. Serum protein electrophoresis: Not indicated in the routine evaluation of diabetes and is used to diagnose conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

choices.text: Nodular sclerosis is the most common and involves the mediastinum
CD15 & CD30 positivity in Reed Sternberg cells
Reed Sternberg cells are derived from B cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is/are incorrect about Hodgkin's lymphoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Waldeyer’s ring is commonly involved

 

The statement that Waldeyer's ring is commonly involved in Hodgkin's lymphoma is incorrect. In classic Hodgkin's lymphoma, involvement of Waldeyer's ring and mesenteric nodes is very unlikely. This is typically seen in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, not in classic Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Nodular sclerosis is the most common and involves the mediastinum: This is correct. Nodular sclerosis is indeed the most common histological type of Hodgkin's lymphoma worldwide, and it typically involves the mediastinum.

 

Option C. CD15 & CD30 positivity in Reed Sternberg cells: This is correct. CD15 and CD30 positivity is a classic feature of Reed Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma. In fact, this characteristic is exploited in targeted therapy, such as the use of Brentuximab-Vedotin, an antibody-drug conjugate against CD30, for refractory classic Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Reed Sternberg cells are derived from B cells: This is correct. Reed Sternberg cells are indeed derived from B cells, specifically from "crippled" B cells in the lymph node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic Hodgkin's lymphoma, Waldeyer's ring involvement is uncommon, unlike in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The disease typically involves the mediastinum, with nodular sclerosis being the most common histological type.

questions.text: A patient undergoes PRBC transfusion. Which of the following is incorrect with regards to Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cola coloured urine Occurs > 2 hours

 

In a Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (DHTR), symptoms typically appear after 24 hours of transfusion, sometimes even days or weeks later. The statement that cola-colored urine occurs > 2 hours is incorrect for DHTR. This dark urine, indicative of hemoglobinuria due to intravascular hemolysis, is a characteristic feature of DHTR but occurs much later than 2 hours post-transfusion. In DHTR, the hemolysis is delayed because it takes time for the patient's immune system to mount a secondary response to the transfused red blood cells.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Failure of Hb to rise: This is correct for DHTR. Despite transfusion, the hemoglobin level does not increase as expected due to the destruction of transfused red blood cells.

 

Option C. Increased Indirect Bilirubin: This is correct. As red blood cells are destroyed in DHTR, there's an increase in indirect bilirubin, a byproduct of hemoglobin breakdown.

 

Option D. Increased S. LDH: This is correct. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels increase in DHTR due to the release of this enzyme from lysed red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction, symptoms including cola-colored urine appear after 24 hours of transfusion, not within 2 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery with rocuronium as a muscle relaxant and has not regained muscle function post-surgery. Which of the following can result in the fastest reversal? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

Rocuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used during surgery to induce muscle relaxation. After surgery, the reversal of its effects is crucial to restore muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent specifically designed to encapsulate and inactivate rocuronium and vecuronium. Sugammadex rapidly reverses the effects of these muscle relaxants by forming a tight complex with the drug, thereby preventing it from binding to nicotinic receptors. This results in the fastest reversal of neuromuscular blockade caused by rocuronium.

 

Note – A new drug called calabadion is a broad-spectrum that can be used for the reversal of every single neuromuscular blocking agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine: An acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thus competing with non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like rocuronium. However, its action is not as rapid as sugammadex and is generally used for a broader range of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers.

 

Option C. Edrophonium: Another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used primarily in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis rather than for reversing neuromuscular blockade in surgical settings.

 

Option D. Atropine: An anticholinergic drug that does not have any role in reversing neuromuscular blockade as it targets muscarinic receptors. It is used to counteract bradycardia and to reduce salivation during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the fastest and most specific agent for reversing the effects of rocuronium by directly encapsulating the drug and preventing its action at the neuromuscular junction.

choices.text: IgM is the most common antibody in ABO
ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth
Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent

questions.text: Regarding ABO blood grouping, which statement is false? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth

 

The statement "ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth" is false. While ABO antibodies are indeed considered natural antibodies, they are not present at birth. These antibodies develop through a process called molecular mimicry after exposure to gut commensals. Typically, ABO antibodies begin to appear around 3 to 6 months of age, not immediately after birth as the statement suggests.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IgM is the most common antibody in ABO: This statement is correct. IgM is the predominant antibody type in the ABO blood group system. This characteristic is important because IgM antibodies, due to their large size, cannot cross the placenta, which is crucial for preventing complications during pregnancy.

 

Option C. ABO antigens are carbohydrates:  This statement is correct. ABO antigens are oligosaccharides, which are carbohydrate structures. This fact has been established and discussed multiple times in the context of blood group antigens.

 

Option D. Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent: This statement is also correct. In the ABO blood group system, an individual's blood will contain antibodies against the ABO antigens that are not present on their own red blood cells. This principle is fundamental to understanding ABO blood group compatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABO antibodies, while natural, are not present at birth but develop in the first few months of life (typically 3-6 months) through exposure to environmental factors, particularly gut bacteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with regurgitation of food and weight loss over the past several months. A barium swallow is performed. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The patient presents with symptoms of regurgitation and weight loss, and a barium swallow shows a characteristic "bird's beak" appearance. This finding is highly suggestive of achalasia cardia.

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a functional obstruction of the esophagus. The classic radiographic feature seen on a barium swallow is a smooth, tapered narrowing at the lower esophagus resembling a bird's beak. Symptoms include progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and weight loss.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Esophageal carcinoma: While esophageal carcinoma can present with similar symptoms, it typically occurs in older patients (50yr+) and may produce a similar radiographic appearance, known as "pseudoachalasia." However, the age of the patient and the classic bird's beak appearance make achalasia the more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition involves the formation of a diverticulum in the hypopharynx, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. The radiographic appearance is different, typically showing a pouch at the back of the throat, rather than the bird's beak seen in achalasia.

 

Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm: This condition presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain. The barium swallow typically shows a corkscrew esophagus due to simultaneous, uncoordinated contractions, which is distinct from the bird's beak appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a bird's beak appearance on a barium swallow. This is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with regurgitation of food and weight loss.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman sign, also known as Hamman's mediastinal crunch, is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is caused by air in the mediastinum, which is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity. The presence of air in this area leads to a characteristic sound as the heart beats, which can be heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. Clinical signs include guarding, rigidity, and air under the diaphragm visible on imaging. Hamman sign is not associated with pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option B. Pneumopericardium: This condition involves air within the pericardial cavity surrounding the heart. While it can cause similar auscultatory findings, it does not specifically present with Hamman sign.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. A significant clinical finding here is straight-line dullness on percussion, not Hamman sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 5 days and retro-orbital pain, suggestive of dengue fever. Which investigation should be conducted next for confirmation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgM ELISA

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of dengue fever for 5 days, the most appropriate test for confirmation is IgM ELISA. According to national dengue guidelines, NS1 antigen testing is most effective in the first 1-4 days of illness. However, from day 5 onwards, IgM antibodies become detectable, making IgM ELISA the preferred test for confirmation at this stage of the illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NS1 antigen test: While useful for early detection (days 1-4), it's less effective after 5 days of symptoms.

 

Option B. Viral culture: Though it can be used for dengue diagnosis, it's not the preferred method due to time constraints and complexity.

 

Option C. PCR: While sensitive, PCR is most useful in the early stages of infection and may not be the best choice after 5 days of symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For dengue fever confirmation after 5 days of symptoms, IgM ELISA is the most appropriate diagnostic test according to national guidelines.

questions.text:
Which of the following are signs of heart failure? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Non-pulsatile rise of JVP
  2. Orthopnea
  3. Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep
  4. Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Heart failure presents with a range of symptoms due to the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively. The following signs are indicative of heart failure:

 

  • Orthopnea (Option 2): This is difficulty breathing when lying flat and is a common symptom of left-sided heart failure.
  • Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep (Option 3): Also known as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), this occurs due to fluid redistribution during sleep, leading to pulmonary congestion.
  • Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain (Option 4): This is associated with right-sided heart failure leading to congestive hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Non-pulsatile rise of JVP): This is incorrect as heart failure typically causes a pulsatile rise in jugular venous pressure (JVP). A non-pulsatile rise in JVP is usually indicative of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, not heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs of heart failure include orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), and right upper quadrant pain due to congestive hepatomegaly.

choices.text: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation:  

 

The spirometry graph compares a normal patient's lung function with that of the patient. The normal graph shows an FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) of more than 70%, which is typical in healthy individuals. In contrast, the patient's graph shows a significantly reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of approximately 50-55%, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

 

Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced airflow due to airway narrowing or obstruction, leading to a lower FEV1/FVC ratio. The common obstructive lung diseases include asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, COPD, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: This typically causes restrictive lung disease, not obstructive, and would present with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio but reduced lung volumes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is an interstitial lung disease, which is restrictive. It would show a normal or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced lung volumes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Another interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive patterns on spirometry, characterized by a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced total lung capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is indicative of obstructive lung disease. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the obstructive lung disease associated with this spirometry pattern.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

 

The patient presents with a productive cough characterized by tenacious white sputum. In such cases, it is essential to use a treatment that helps break down and clear the mucus to prevent further complications like infections.

 

Syrup Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that works by breaking down mucus, making it easier to clear from the respiratory tract. This is the most appropriate treatment for a patient with thick, tenacious sputum as it will help in liquefying the mucus and promoting its expulsion through coughing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: This combination does not make sense therapeutically. Dextromethorphan is an antitussive, which suppresses cough, while bromhexine is a mucolytic, which helps break down mucus. Using them together is illogical because you do not want to suppress the cough when the patient has productive sputum that needs to be expelled.

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: Codeine is also an antitussive and should not be used in patients with productive cough. Suppressing the cough can lead to accumulation of sputum, which can cause infections.

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Similar to codeine, dextromethorphan is an antitussive and is not appropriate for treating a productive cough. It will suppress the cough reflex, leading to retention of mucus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a productive cough and thick, tenacious sputum, mucolytic agents like bromhexine should be used to help break down and clear the mucus, rather than suppressing the cough reflex with antitussives.
